extendedIngredients.name: lobster meat
extendedIngredients.original: 1 lb cooked lobster meat or cooked shrimp, cut into 1/3-inch pieces (about 2 1/2 cups)
extendedIngredients.originalName: cooked lobster meat or cooked shrimp, cut into 1/3-inch pieces (about 2 1/2 cups)

extendedIngredients.name: nonfat yogurt
extendedIngredients.original: 1/2 cup nonfat plain Greek-style yogurt or 2/3 cup regular, plain nonfat yogurt
extendedIngredients.originalName: nonfat plain Greek-style yogurt or 2/3 cup regular, plain nonfat yogurt

extendedIngredients.name: salt and pepper
extendedIngredients.original: Salt and freshly ground black pepper
extendedIngredients.originalName: Salt and freshly ground black pepper

title: Shrimp Rolls
summary: Shrimp Rolls might be just the hor d'oeuvre you are searching for. One serving contains 656 calories, 50g of protein, and 28g of fat. This recipe serves 2. For $13.61 per serving, this recipe covers 37% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. This recipe from Handle the Heat has 1 fans. It is a good option if you're following a pescatarian diet. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes around 45 minutes. If you have celery, nonfat yogurt, scallion greens, and a few other ingredients on hand, you can make it. To use up the olive oil you could follow this main course with the Sauteed Banana, Granolan and Yogurt Parfait as a dessert. With a spoonacular score of 66%, this dish is solid. Similar recipes include Shrimp Egg Rolls, Shrimp Rolls, and Shrimp Rolls.

winePairing.pairingText: Chardonnay, Muscadet, and Riesling are my top picks for Shellfish. Buttery chardonnay is great for scallops, shrimp, crab, and lobster, while muscadet is a classic pick for mussels, oysters, and clams. If you've got some spice in your shellfish, a semi-dry riesling can balance out the heat. One wine you could try is A to Z Chardonnay. It has 4.2 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 15 dollars.

productMatches.title: A to Z Chardonnay
productMatches.description: The 2010 A to Z Chardonnay opens with aromas of white flowers, tangerine, lime, quince, wet stone and minerals that develop further into nutmeg, honey, green apple with hints of ginger. A mineral laden attack is bright, mouthwatering and intense. The nuanced mid-palate carries on with flavors that mirror and amplify the aromatics. The finish is long, clean, crisp and juicy with flavors of honeysuckle, citrus and wet stone. This wine exemplifies classic Oregon steely Chardonnay. 2010 was an exceptional vintage for white wines in Oregon and this sophisticated terroir driven wine is no exception; bright, tangy and intense it will deliver over the next 5 years.

instructions: If using regular yogurt, place it in a strainer lined with paper towel and set the strainer over a bowl. Let the yogurt drain and thicken for 20 minutes.In a bowl, stir together the thickened or Greek-style yogurt, mayonnaise, celery, scallion and lemon juice. Fold in the lobster meat and season, to taste, with salt and pepper. Chill until ready to use. Just before serving, open the hot dog buns and brush the inside with olive oil. Heat a grill pan over moderately high heat and grill the bread, cut side down, until toasted, about 3 minutes. Fill each with 3/4 cup of the lobster mixture and serve immediately.

steps.step: If using regular yogurt, place it in a strainer lined with paper towel and set the strainer over a bowl.

Let the yogurt drain and thicken for 20 minutes.In a bowl, stir together the thickened or Greek-style yogurt, mayonnaise, celery, scallion and lemon juice. Fold in the lobster meat and season, to taste, with salt and pepper. Chill until ready to use. Just before serving, open the hot dog buns and brush the inside with olive oil.
Heat a grill pan over moderately high heat and grill the bread, cut side down, until toasted, about 3 minutes. Fill each with 3/4 cup of the lobster mixture and serve immediately.
